pullRequest.body:
Add `MonoidHom.noncommCoprod` which allows to define a morphism from a product `M x N` 
to a monoid `P` given two monoid morphisms `M -> P` and `N -> P`,
provided a commutativity assumption on the ranges.

---
<!-- The text above the `---` will become the commit message when your
PR is merged. Please leave a blank newline before the `---`, otherwise
GitHub will format the text above it as a title.

To indicate co-authors, include lines at the bottom of the commit message
(that is, before the `---`) using the following format:

Co-authored-by: Author Name <author@email.com>

Any other comments you want to keep out of the PR commit should go
below the `---`, and placed outside this HTML comment, or else they
will be invisible to reviewers.

If this PR depends on other PRs, please list them below this comment,
using the following format:
- [ ] depends on: #abc [optional extra text]
-->
- [x] depends on: #8756

[![Open in Gitpod](https://gitpod.io/button/open-in-gitpod.svg)](https://gitpod.io/from-referrer/)

nodes.body:
This is exactly the same as [this](https://leanprover-community.github.io/mathlib4_docs/Mathlib/GroupTheory/NoncommPiCoprod.html) file but for the product of two things rather than the Pi type, right?

I don't know if it is a good idea to move everything to `NoncommPiCoprod`, but if we keep the two constructions in different files each doc should mention the other file.
Yes, Riccardo, you're right.
I added the comment about `MonoidHom.noncommPiCoprod`.

I think either this content should move to `GroupTheory/NoncommPiCoprod.lean`, or it should go in a new file `GroupTheory/NoncommCoprod.lean`. The advantage of the new file is that it's very easy to compare the API between the `pi` and `prod` cases.
I agree with Eric about a new file, otherwise LGTM.
I'll do that soon, but I need some rest nowâ€¦

```suggestion * (when `P` is commutative) `f.coprod g : M Ã— N â†’* P` sends `(x, y)` to `f x * g y`, ```

```suggestion
* (when `P` is commutative) `f.coprod g : M Ã— N â†’* P` sends `(x, y)` to `f x * g y`,
  and `comm` says that the elements in the ranges of `f` and `g` commute pairwise,
  `f.noncommCoprod g comm` is the analogous `M Ã— N â†’* P`.
```

```suggestion
  toFun := fun mn â†¦ (f mn.fst) * (g mn.snd)
  map_mul' := fun mn mn' â†¦ by
```
```suggestion
  toFun mn := (f mn.fst) * (g mn.snd)
  map_mul' mn mn' := by
```
The trick here is knowing that `mul_mul_mul_comm` exists!

We shouldn't be committing code in comments; though perhaps this was just you asking for feedback on why `simpNF` complains.

I think this lemma is probably fine to have without the `simp` attribute. You might also want to add the one that says how `noncommCoprod` composes with whatever the name of the multiplicative map `(x, y) => (y, x)` is.

I think I can remove it.
What you suggest would be obtained using MulHom.comp, so I'm not sure it is necessary to add it.
(And I don't use noncommProd anymore nowâ€¦)
The trick here is to note that the `simp only` line looks like obvious definitional equalities, so can be removed.
This one is a pretty important trick; don't reprove the same thing again if you can re-use the existing structure from the `MulHom`.
I removed this lemma, as the name was a bit strange, the lemma isn't in simpNF (if it were, the `comp` would be eliminated) and `(inl_inr_commute _ _).map f` is a pretty short proof.
Feel free to add this one back (not in a comment) if you want to keep it.

```suggestion
    (Commutative codomain; for the general case, see `AddHom.noncommCoprod`)"]
```
I split the file for you, but this docstring still needs writing

I had forgotten about this PR, thank you for having revived it.
I just added the docstring and fixed an error (due to a change of names).

```suggestion
  and if `comm` says that the elements in the ranges of `f` and `g` commute pairwise,
```
I have the impression the sentence is a little unclear.
I'm not even sure what `comm` refers to here; is this intended for the docstring in the other file?
It is the name of the assumption. Anyway we agree that it is not clear.
`coprod` has no such assumption.

I made a small change in the formulation by adding a new item for the noncommProd,
I believe it is clearer now.
This is in a list of things defined in this file, but is not defined in this file!
